I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reading & writing in Chinese, how to communicate clearly in Chinese, Chinese vocabulary & philosophy
I definitely learned a lot about the Chinese language, but I think the most valuable thing I'm taking away from this course is Su Laoshi's discussion of modern China.

I primarily developed my speaking, reading, and writing (mostly typing given the online format) abilities, whereas listening was a skill that many of the students were very confident in. All aspects of course content are designed to cover a wide range of relevant Chinese culture, anything from ancient Chinese adages to modern day issues in China and around the world.
I learned lots of vocabulary along with Chinese culture and societal issues.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed this course, Su laoshi has a ton of knowledge and is great to learn from. The variety of information we got to learn was really cool.

A great strength of this course is definitely Su Laoshi. From what I could tell, he's just as passionate about teaching as he is with Chinese in general. He is very personable and with his opportunities to each lunch with him every Friday, you really feel like you get to know your classmates and Su Laoshi a lot better. Su Laoshi also often incorporates his knowledge about China in general, and I really enjoyed him recounting stories. 

As for an improvement, I think one thing that I would've enjoyed learning about more is the etymology behind new words we learn, such as why a certain word is written the way it is, as well as perhaps more time being spent on simplified vs traditional chinese.

The course is incredibly well-designed, and Su Laoshi makes learning Chinese very interesting and rewarding. A lot of the course material was designed to help us learn useful things and learn them in a way that sticks. In my opinion, the only thing this course lacked was practice on handwriting Chinese, but the online Zoom format accounts for most of that, and I imagine that there is more practice with handwritten tasks during a normal semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't know if there were practices geared toward learning during COVID, but I think that the course was fairly engaging, especially because our class was on the smaller size.
Mandatory zoom discussions sounded like a pain at first, but looking back I know for sure that I wouldn't have learned nearly as much as I not attended these classes.
The small Zoom environment went very smoothly, and it was easy to stay engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I learned a lot from it and I think that it not only improved my Chinese language ability but also my understanding of Chinese culture.
Yes, for anyone that is considering the possibility of interacting with China in the future, or is just genuinely devoted to learning the Chinese language.

Absolutely, especially to students who dreaded learning Chinese as a kid. This class has probably been my favorite class at Yale so far, and you will never go wrong with taking a class with Su Laoshi. The class is engaging, incredibly rewarding, and dare I say... fun.
Yes! It is a wonderful way to learn not just Chinese but also maintain intellectual interest through discussion of idioms and societal issues.

I would only recommend this class to students who already have a really strong foundation because the course is very unstructured and relies heavily on pre-existing knowledge or extensive outside help (from parents or tutoring options). This is an "easy" class if you're already good at Chinese and don't need to learn language skills from class -- most of our time was spent with the professor telling personal stories, and we never went over grammar or vocab, despite each having over 100 vocab words on average per chapter. Besides exams, it felt relaxed because deadlines for assignments were flexible, regular homework assignments weren't graded with corrections, and most textbook exercises were done in class. However, there wasn't much detailed explanation or applied practice that's more typical of other Yale language courses (as someone who took 152 and 153). The professor himself is very nice and caring, but his expectations of what you're learning from this class is less about skills and more about exploring higher level concept about Chinese culture and society with topics like government corruption, migrant workers, etc -- it's a class about bringing new interesting topics into discussion. For example, essay and presentations assignments are graded mostly on how new and exciting the content is rather than how well the vocab and grammar introduced in the textbook is used. So, if you're already good at Chinese and just wanna vibe with a professor that tells stories, take this class. If you feel like you're still in need of building up your language skills, I would not recommend unless you're willing to make it your biggest priority.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lots on learning done with homework for sure!
